results.title: Blood brothers
results.creator_credit: Jessica Cribb, Rebecca Parker and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Paul and Ben are blood brothers. They’ve got heaps of brothers and sisters, but they’re the only ones with the same mum and dad. They live in Willmot, an isolated community on the outskirts of Western Sydney. It’s a no-go zone, a suburban wasteland with huge powerlines overhead. Paul and Ben struggle to survive poverty, “westie” stigma, violence and abuse. Each has their own way of keeping feelings of powerlessness and fear at bay but, ultimately, they have each other. Their story is about family, love, loyalty and what it truly means to be a blood brother.

results.title: Bias
results.creator_credit: Alice Addison, Steve Pasvolsky, Catriona McKenzie and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Two old men are playing for the champion’s rosette in lawn bowls when a snail interupts play and causes one codger to win and the other to lose. The battle takes on a greater moral dimension…Animation and live action.
Cast: Lisle Jones, John Keightley

results.title: B.L.A.C.K.: an Aboriginal song of hip hop
results.creator_credit: Roslyn Baker, Grant Saunders and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
B.L.A.C.K. is a cipher scribed by independent and Indigenous Hip Hop artist, Wire MC. Through interviews and observation the song is visually and dialectically deconstructed to speak of contemporary issues around Aboriginal blackness, politics and culture.
The filmmaker, with his own roots in Hip Hop, aligns himself with Wire MC and through a rapped narrative adds another layer of complexity to notions of blackness by pulling apart his own identity.
This is a musical documentary that exposes an authentic and empowering B.L.A.C.K. voice existing underneath the hype of “bling-bling” hip hop. This is a film with rhythm, rhyme and reason.
results.title_for_label: B.L.A.C.K.: an Aboriginal song of hip hop
results.description:

This is a musical documentary that exposes an authentic and empowering B.L.A.C.K. voice existing underneath the hype of “bling-bling” hip hop. This is a film with rhythm, rhyme and reason.

results.title: Arcadia
results.creator_credit: Greg Waters, Paola Garofali, Adrian Wills and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
‘I know that you’re there, because I can feel you. Why don’t you come out and play with me. In the dark I hear you breathing. Watch out for the Hairy Man…’
In Arcadia nothing is what it seems.
Cast: Hunter Page, Justine Saunders, Ursula Yovich, Damien Garvey, Pauline Lampton

results.title: Agnes, Maude and Pearly too
results.creator_credit: Kate Gillick, Charles Mitchell, Aline Jacques, Erica Glynn and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
On this day, in loving memory of Pearly, Agnes and Maude play a game on Pearly’s favourite poker machine. But when they hit the jackpot, money isn’t the only thing that comes spilling out.
Cast: Julie Godfrey (Agnes), Jacquy Phillips (Maude)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kate Gillick, Charles Mitchell, Aline Jacques, Erica Glynn and AFTRS
results.description:
On this day, in loving memory of Pearly, Agnes and Maude play a game on Pearly’s favourite poker machine. But when they hit the jackpot, money isn’t the only thing that comes spilling out.
Cast: Julie Godfrey (Agnes), Jacquy Phillips (Maude)
description_for_label:
On this day, in loving memory of Pearly, Agnes and Maude play a game on Pearly’s favourite poker machine. But when they hit the jackpot, money isn’t the only thing that comes spilling out.
Cast: Julie Godfrey (Agnes), Jacquy Phillips (Maude)

results.title: Contentment
results.creator_credit: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.
description_for_label: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.

results.title: Strong and Proud
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Darren Atkinson
results.brief_description: Darren grew up on Cummeragunja Mission and in this digital story he talks about his grandfather’s life, the Koori community and the handing down of Indigenous traditions and culture from one generation to the next.
results.description: Darren grew up on Cummeragunja Mission and in this digital story he talks about his grandfather’s life, the Koori community and the handing down of Indigenous traditions and culture from one generation to the next.

results.title: Buddurri Healing
results.creator_credit: Jason Davis, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Identity - Dreaming - Destruction - Healing - Sharing - Unity - Hunting - Identity.’ This is Jason Davis’ healing story and about his connection to his Indigenous culture.

results.title: Streets of Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Mick Booth
results.brief_description: Mick Booth was brought up in Kent Street, Fitzroy - an inner suburb of Melbourne. This is his story of childhood memories, family and growing up in Fitzroy.
results.description: Mick Booth was brought up in Kent Street, Fitzroy - an inner suburb of Melbourne. This is his story of childhood memories, family and growing up in Fitzroy.

results.title: Leaving My Country
results.creator_credit: Grant Hood, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: An argument with his uncle one night would turn out to be a life-changing experience for Grant Hood, a proud Kurnai Gunai man. Grant mentions the importance of his meeting with Kutcha Edwards when he first arrives in Melbourne. A photo of a very young Kutcha is also shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Hood, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: An argument with his uncle one night would turn out to be a life-changing experience for Grant Hood, a proud Kurnai Gunai man. Grant mentions the importance of his meeting with Kutcha Edwards when he first arrives in Melbourne. A photo of a very young Kutcha is also shown.
